Founded in 1988, initially as a [[Enterprise risk management|risk management]] and [[fixed income]] institutional [[asset manager]], BlackRock is the world's largest asset manager, with {{currency|10|USD}} trillion in [[assets under management]] as of January 2022.{{Cite news|last1=Wigglesworth|first1=Robin|last2=Agnew|first2=Harriet|date=2022-01-14|title=BlackRock surges past $10tn in assets under management|work=Financial Times|url=https://www.ft.com/content/7603e676-779b-4c13-8f46-a964594e3c2f |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/archive/pN2vz |archive-date=2022-12-11 |url-access=subscription |url-status=live|access-date=2022-01-15}} BlackRock operates globally with 70 offices in 30 countries, and clients in 100 countries.{{Citation |title=BlackRock's Current Share |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/greatspeculations/2017/07/18/blackrocks-current-share-price-doesnt-capture-its-long-term-growth-prospects/#22272cbea95a |work=Forbes |access-date=July 26, 2017}} Along with [[The Vanguard Group|Vanguard]] and [[State Street Corporation|State Street]], BlackRock is considered to be one of the Big Three index fund managers that dominate corporate America.{{Cite journal |last1=Bebchuk |first1=Lucian |author-link=Lucian Bebchuk |last2=Hirst |first2=Scott |date=2019 |title=Index Funds and the Future of Corporate Governance: Theory, Evidence, and Policy |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/features/2020-01-09/the-hidden-dangers-of-the-great-index-fund-takeover |access-date=June 7, 2021 |website=Bloomberg Businessweek}} BlackRock has sought to position itself as an industry leader in [[environmental, social and corporate governance]] (ESG). The company has faced criticism for worsening [[climate change]], its close ties with the [[Federal reserve system|Federal Reserve System]] during the [[COVID-19 pandemic]], [[Anti-competitive practices|anticompetitive behavior]], and its unprecedented investments in [[China]].{{Cite news |last=Soros |first=George |date=2021-09-06 |title=Opinion {{!}} BlackRock's China Blunder |language=en-US |work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/blackrock-larry-fink-china-hkex-sse-authoritarianism-xi-jinping-term-limits-human-rights-ant-didi-global-national-security-11630938728 |access-date=2022-03-24 |issn=0099-9660}}{{Cite web |last=Meredith |first=Sam |date=2021-09-08 |title=BlackRock responds to George Soros' criticism over China investments |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2021/09/08/blackrock-responds-to-george-soros-criticism-over-china-investments.html |access-date=2022-03-24 |website=CNBC |language=en}} == History == === 1988–1997=== BlackRock was founded in 1988 by [[Larry Fink]], [[Robert S. Kapito]], [[Susan Wagner]], Barbara Novick, Ben Golub, Hugh Frater, Ralph Schlosstein, and Keith Anderson{{Cite web |last=Appell |first=Douglas |date=2012-07-09 |title=BlackRock departures spur talk about Fink's future |url=https://www.pionline.com/article/20120709/PRINT/307099977/blackrock-departures-spur-talk-about-finks-future |access-date=2019-04-15 |website=Pensions & Investments |language=en}} to provide institutional clients with asset management services from a risk management perspective.{{Cite news |date=2013-12-05 |title=The rise of BlackRock |newspaper=The Economist |url=https://www.economist.com/leaders/2013/12/05/the-rise-of-blackrock |access-date=2019-04-15 |issn=0013-0613}} Fink, Kapito, Golub and Novick had worked together at [[First Boston]], where Fink and his team were pioneers in the [[Mortgage-backed security|mortgage-backed securities]] market in the United States.{{Cite news |title=Larry Fink Q&A: "I Don't Identify as Powerful" |newspaper=Bloomberg.com |publisher=Bloomberg |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/features/2017-blackrock-larry-fink-interview/ |access-date=2019-04-15 }} During Fink's tenure, he had lost $90 million as head of First Boston. That experience was the motivation to develop what he and the others considered to be excellent risk management and fiduciary practices. Initially, Fink sought funding (for initial operating capital) from Pete Peterson of [[The Blackstone Group]] who believed in Fink's vision of a firm devoted to risk management. Peterson called it Blackstone Financial Management.{{Cite book |last1=Carey |first1=David |last2=Morris |first2=John E. |date=2012 |title=King of Capital: The Remarkable Rise, Fall, and Rise Again of Steve Schwarzman and Blackstone |publisher=Crown Publishing Group |isbn=9780307886026 |page=59 |language=en |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DE8jTajp7PAC&pg=PA59 }} In exchange for a 50 percent stake in the bond business, initially Blackstone gave Fink and his team a $5 million credit line. Within months, the business had turned profitable, and by 1989 the group's assets had quadrupled to $2.7 billion. The percent of the stake owned by Blackstone also fell to 40%, compared to Fink's staff. By 1992, Blackstone had a stake equating to about 35% of the company, and [[Stephen A. Schwarzman]] and Fink were considering selling shares to the public. The firm adopted the name BlackRock, and was managing $17 billion in assets by the end of the year. At the end of 1994, BlackRock was managing $53 billion.{{Citation |title=History |url=https://www.blackrock.com/corporate/en-cn/about-us/blackrock-history |publisher=BlackRock |access-date=May 9, 2017}} In 1994, Schwarzman and Fink had an internal dispute over methods of compensation and equity. Fink wanted to share equity with new hires, to lure talent from [[bank]]s, unlike Schwarzman, who did not want to further lower Blackstone's stake. They agreed to part ways, and Schwarzman sold BlackRock, a decision he later called a "heroic mistake."{{cite news |title=Schwarzman Says Selling BlackRock Was 'Heroic' Mistake |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2013-09-30/schwarzman-says-selling-blackrock-was-heroic-mistake |access-date=26 October 2021 |work=Bloomberg.com |date=30 September 2013 |language=en}}{{cite news |last1=Foley |first1=John |last2=Cox |first2=Rob |title=BlackRock is Wall Street's object of fantasy M&A |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-blackrock-blackstone-group-breakingvi/breakingviews-blackrock-is-wall-streets-object-of-fantasy-ma-idUSKBN1YR1JI |access-date=26 October 2021 |work=Reuters |date=23 December 2019 |language=en}} In June 1994, Blackstone sold a mortgage-securities unit with $23 billion in assets to [[PNC Financial Services Group|PNC Bank Corp.]] for $240 million. The unit had traded mortgages and other fixed-income assets, and during the sales process the unit changed its name from Blackstone Financial Management to BlackRock Financial Management. Schwarzman remained with Blackstone, while Fink went on to become chairman and CEO of BlackRock Inc. === 1999–2009 === BlackRock went public in 1999 at $14 a share{{Cite web |title=Corporate History |url=https://www.pnc.com/webapp/unsec/NCProductsAndService.do?siteArea=/pnccorp/PNC/Home/About+PNC/Our+Organization/Corporate+History |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120517183033/https://www.pnc.com/webapp/unsec/NCProductsAndService.do?siteArea=%2Fpnccorp%2FPNC%2FHome%2FAbout+PNC%2FOur+Organization%2FCorporate+History |archive-date=May 17, 2012 |access-date=2014-03-22}} on the [[New York Stock Exchange]]. By the end of 1999, BlackRock was managing $165 billion in assets. BlackRock grew both organically and by acquisition. In August 2004, BlackRock made its first major acquisition, buying [[State Street Research & Management]]'s holding company SSRM Holdings, Inc. from [[MetLife]] for $325 million in cash and $50 million in stock. The acquisition raised BlackRock's assets under management from $314 billion to $325 billion.{{Cite web |date=August 24, 2004 |title=BlackRock Acquiring State Street Research from MetLife |url=https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20040826005225/en/BlackRock-Purchase-SSRM-Holdings-MetLife-BlackRock-Hold |website=businesswire.com}} The deal included the mutual-fund business State Street Research & Management in 2005. BlackRock merged with [[Merrill Lynch|Merrill Lynch Investment Managers]] (MLIM) in 2006,{{Cite news |date=February 16, 2006 |title=BlackRock and a hard place |newspaper=[[The Economist]] |url=http://www.economist.com/node/5531382 |access-date=May 9, 2017}} halving PNC's ownership and giving [[Merrill Lynch]] a 49.5% stake in the company.{{Cite web |last=Spence |first=John |title=BlackRock, Merrill fund unit complete merger |url=https://www.marketwatch.com/story/merrill-lynch-investment-managers-blackrock-close-merger |access-date=2019-04-11 |website=MarketWatch |language=en-US}} In October 2007, BlackRock acquired the fund-of-funds business of Quellos Capital Management.{{Cite web |date=2007-06-26 |title=BlackRock to Acquire Fund of Funds Business from Quellos Group, LLC |url=http://www2.blackrock.com/content/groups/global/documents/literature/qpr_062507_bb.pdf}} BlackRock, Inc.{{Cite web |last=DeSilver |first=Drew |date=2007-06-27 |title=Quellos is selling unit to BlackRock in $1.72 billion deal |url=https://www.seattletimes.com/business/quellos-is-selling-unit-to-blackrock-in-172-billion-deal/ |access-date=2020-03-10 |website=The Seattle Times |language=en-US}} The U.S. government contracted with BlackRock to help resolve the fallout of the [[Late-2000s financial crisis|financial meltdown of 2008]]. According to ''[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]'', the financial establishment in [[Washington, D.C.|Washington]] and on [[Wall Street]] believed BlackRock was the best choice for the job.Andrews, Suzanna. [http://www.vanityfair.com/business/features/2010/04/fink-201004 Larry Fink's $12 Trillion Shadow], ''Vanity Fair'', April 2010: "There is little doubt among the financial establishment in Washington and on Wall Street that BlackRock was the best choice to handle the government's problems." The [[Federal Reserve]] allowed BlackRock to superintend the $130 billion-debt settlement of [[Bear Stearns]] and [[American International Group]]. In 2009, BlackRock first became the No. 1 asset manager worldwide. In April 2009, BlackRock acquired R3 Capital Management, LLC and took control of the $1.5 billion fund.{{Cite news |date=April 17, 2009 |title=BlackRock to Acquire R3 Capital |work=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2009/04/17/blackrock-to-acquire-r3-capital/ |access-date=May 9, 2017}} On 12 June 2009, [[Barclays]] sold its Global Investors unit (BGI), which included its exchange traded fund business, [[iShares]], to BlackRock for US$13.5 billion. Through the deal, Barclays attained a near-20% stake in BlackRock.{{Cite news |date=12 June 2009 |title=US giant BlackRock buys arm of Barclays bank | ''The Guardian''. |work=The Guardian |agency=Press Association |location=UK |url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2009/jun/12/blackrock-to-buy-barclays-bank-arm |access-date=21 February 2010}} ===2010–2019=== In 2010, Ralph Schlosstein, the CEO of [[Evercore Partners]] and a BlackRock founder, called BlackRock "the most influential financial institution in the world."{{Cite web |last=Kolhatkar |first=Sheelah |date=December 9, 2010 |title=Fink Builds BlackRock Powerhouse Without Goldman Sachs Backlash |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-12-09/larry-fink-builds-blackrock-into-powerhouse-without-goldman-sachs-backlash.html |access-date=April 20, 2013 |publisher=Bloomberg}} On 1 April 2011, due to [[Sanofi|Sanofi's]] acquisition of [[Genzyme]], BlackRock replaced it on the [[S&P 500]] index.{{Cite web |date=2011-03-29 |title=BlackRock to join S&P 500 index, replacing Genzyme |url=http://www.businessweek.com/ap/financialnews/D9M964IO0.htm |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121026050853/http://www.businessweek.com/ap/financialnews/D9M964IO0.htm |archive-date=2012-10-26 |website=Bloomberg Businessweek}} Retrieved January 23, 2012. In 2013, ''Fortune'' listed BlackRock on its annual list of the world's 50 Most Admired Companies.{{Cite news |date=July 7, 2014 |title=BlackRock: The $4.3 trillion force |work=[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]] |url=http://fortune.com/2014/07/07/blackrock-larry-fink/ |access-date=May 9, 2017}} In 2014, ''The Economist'' said that BlackRock's $4 trillion under management made it the "world's biggest asset manager", and it was larger than the world's largest bank, the [[Industrial and Commercial Bank of China]], with $3 trillion.{{Cite news |last= |date=May 10, 2014 |title=Shadow and substance |newspaper=[[The Economist]] |url=https://www.economist.com/news/special-report/21601621-banks-retreat-wake-financial-crisis-shadow-banks-are-taking-growing |access-date=May 8, 2017}} In May of the same year, BlackRock invested in [[Snapdeal]].{{Cite web |title=Snapdeal raises $100M in fresh funding from BlackRock, Temasek, PremjiInvest, others |url=http://www.vccircle.com/news/technology/2014/05/21/snapdeal-raises-100m-fresh-funding-blackrock-temasek-premjiinvest-others |publisher=VC Circle}} In December 2014 a BlackRock managing director in London was banned by the British [[Financial Conduct Authority]] for failing the "fit and proper" test, because he paid £43,000 to avoid prosecution for dodging train fares. In response to the incident, BlackRock said, "Jonathan Burrows left BlackRock earlier this year. What he admitted to the FCA is totally contrary to our values and principles."{{Cite web |last=Rankin |first=Jennifer |date=December 15, 2014 |title=FCA bans £43,000 fare dodger from working in financial services |url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2014/dec/15/ca-ban-43000-fare-dodger-financial-services-industry-blackrock-jonathan-burrows |via=www.theguardian.com}}{{Cite news |date=15 December 2014 |title=FCA Life Ban For Fare-Dodging Jonathan Burrows |publisher=Sky News |url=http://news.sky.com/story/1392280/fca-life-ban-for-fare-dodging-jonathan-burrows |access-date=15 December 2014}} At the end of 2014, the [[Sovereign Wealth Fund Institute]] reported that 65% of Blackrock's assets under management were made up of [[institutional investor]]s.{{Cite web |date=n.d. |title=Is BlackRock Too Big |url=https://www.swfinstitute.org/news/26040/is-blackrock-too-big |access-date=9 February 2015 |website=Sovereign Wealth Fund Institute}} By June 30, 2015, BlackRock had US$4.721 trillion of assets under management.{{Cite news |date=2016-07-14 |title=BlackRock profit falls as shift from stocks hits fee revenue |language=en |work=Reuters |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-blackrock-results-idUSKCN0ZU13V |access-date=2019-01-15}} On August 26, 2015, BlackRock entered into a definitive agreement to acquire [[FutureAdvisor]],{{Cite web |title=BlackRock to Acquire FutureAdvisor |url=http://phx.corporate-ir.net/phoenix.zhtml?c=119943&p=irol-newsArticle&ID=2082123 |access-date=26 August 2015 |website=BlackRock Press Releases |publisher=BlackRock}} a digital wealth management provider with reported assets under management of $600 million.{{Cite web |last=Tepper |first=Fitz |date=24 June 2015 |title=YC Alum FutureAdvisor Is Now Managing $600 Million In Assets |url=https://techcrunch.com/2015/06/24/yc-alum-futureadvisor-is-now-managing-600-million/ |access-date=12 September 2015 |publisher=TechCrunch}} Under the deal, FutureAdvisor would operate as a business within BlackRock Solutions (BRS). BlackRock announced in November 2015 that they would wind down the BlackRock Global Ascent hedge fund after losses. The Global Ascent fund had been its only dedicated global macro fund, as BlackRock was "better known for its mutual funds and exchange traded funds." At the time, BlackRock managed $51 billion in hedge funds, with $20 billion of that in funds of hedge funds.{{Cite news |last=Stevenson |first=Alexandra |date=2015-11-18 |title=BlackRock to Wind Down Macro Hedge Fund |work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/11/19/business/dealbook/blackrock-to-wind-down-macro-hedge-fund.html |access-date=2015-11-19 |issn=0362-4331}} In March 2017, the ''[[Financial Times]]'' announced that BlackRock, after a six-month review led by [[Mark Wiseman]], had initiated a restructuring of its $8bn actively-managed fund business, resulting in the departure of seven portfolio managers and a $25m charge in Q2, replacing certain funds with quantitative investment strategies.{{Cite news |date=27 March 2017 |title=BlackRock cuts ranks of stockpicking fund managers |work=[[Financial Times]] |url=https://www.ft.com/content/b0056320-13e3-11e7-b0c1-37e417ee6c76 |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/archive/BVkup |archive-date=2022-12-11 |url-status=live |access-date=30 March 2017|url-access=subscription}} In May 2017, BlackRock increased its stake in both [[CRH plc]] and [[Bank of Ireland]].{{Cite news |last=Hamilton |first=Peter |date=May 8, 2017 |title=BlackRock increases stakes in CRH and Bank of Ireland |work=[[Irish Times]] |url=http://www.irishtimes.com/business/markets/blackrock-increases-stakes-in-crh-and-bank-of-ireland-1.3075209 |access-date=May 8, 2017}} By April 2017, [[iShares]] business accounted for $1.41tn, or 26 percent, of BlackRock's total assets under management, and 37 percent of BlackRock's base fee income.{{Cite news |last=Foley |first=Stephen |date=April 19, 2017 |title=BlackRock assets under management hit $5.4tn on record ETF inflows |work=[[Financial Times]] |url=https://www.ft.com/content/adeae206-2502-11e7-8691-d5f7e0cd0a16 |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/archive/6YUDT |archive-date=2022-12-11 |url-status=live |access-date=May 10, 2017|url-access=subscription}} In April 2017, BlackRock backed the inclusion of mainland Chinese shares in MSCI's global index for the first time.{{Cite news |last=Hughes |first=Jennifer |date=April 20, 2017 |title=BlackRock backs mainland China shares for MSCI benchmarks |work=[[Financial Times]] |url=https://www.ft.com/content/6f0943e6-257c-11e7-8691-d5f7e0cd0a16 |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/archive/1PiMS |archive-date=2022-12-11 |url-status=live |access-date=May 10, 2017|url-access=subscription}} Between October and December 2018, BlackRock's assets dropped by US$468bn and fell below $6tn. It was the largest decline between quarters since September 2011.{{Cite web |title=About BlackRock |url=https://www.blackrock.com/sg/en/about-us |language=en-US}} As of 2019, BlackRock holds 4.81% of [[Deutsche Bank]], making it the single largest shareholder.[https://www.db.com/ir/en/shareholder-structure.htm Deutsche Bank: Shareholder Structure], May 20, 2019 This investment goes back to at least 2016.{{Internet Archive|id=20160927204605|name=Deutsche Bank: Shareholder Structure}}, archived September 27, 2016 In May 2019, BlackRock received criticism for the environmental impact of its holdings.{{Cite news |date=May 21, 2019 |title=World's biggest investor accused of dragging feet on climate crisis |url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2019/may/21/blackrock-investor-climate-crisis-blackrock-assets}} It is counted among the top three shareholders in every oil "[[supermajors|supermajor]]" except [[Total S.A.|Total]], and it is among the top 10 shareholders in 7 of the 10 biggest coal producers. === Since 2020 === In his 2020 annual open letter, Fink announced [[Sustainability|environmental sustainability]] as a core goal for BlackRock's future investment decisions.{{Cite news |last=Sorkin |first=Andrew Ross |date=2020-01-14 |title=BlackRock C.E.O. Larry Fink: Climate Crisis Will Reshape Finance |language=en-US |work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/14/business/dealbook/larry-fink-blackrock-climate-change.html |access-date=2020-01-16 |issn=0362-4331}} BlackRock disclosed plans to sell US$500 million in [[coal]] investments.{{Cite web |title=BlackRock to sell $500 million in coal investments in climate change push |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/blackrock-puts-climate-change-first-in-its-its-investment-strategy/ |access-date=2020-01-16 |website=www.cbsnews.com |language=en-US}} In March 2020, the [[Federal Reserve]] chose BlackRock to manage two corporate bond-buying programs in response to the [[COVID-19 pandemic|coronavirus pandemic]], the $500 billion Primary Market Corporate Credit Facility (PMCCF) and the Secondary Market Corporate Credit Facility (SMCCF), as well as purchase by the Federal Reserve System of commercial mortgage-backed securities (CMBS) guaranteed by [[Government National Mortgage Association]], [[Fannie Mae|Federal National Mortgage Association]], or [[Freddie Mac|Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation]].Annie Massa. [https://web.archive.org/web/20200618233642/https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/why-blackrock-has-a-role-in-the-fed-bond-buying-spree/2020/05/21/853f461c-9b74-11ea-ad79-eef7cd734641_story.html?utm_source=rss&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=wp_business Why BlackRock Has a Role in the Fed Bond-Buying Spree], ''The Washington Post'', May 22, 2020Sophie Baker. [https://www.pionline.com/markets/fed-chooses-blackrock-pandemic-support-programs Fed chooses BlackRock for pandemic support programs], ''Pensions & Investments'', March 25, 2020Jonnelle Marte. This made BlackRock the first global asset manager to get consent from the Chinese government to start operations in the country.{{Cite web |author=Zacks Equity Research |title=BlackRock Gets Nod to Set Up Mutual Fund Business in China (Revised) |url=https://www.nasdaq.com/articles/blackrock-gets-nod-to-set-up-mutual-fund-business-in-china-revised-2020-09-02 |access-date=2020-09-16 |website=www.nasdaq.com |language=en}}{{Cite web |title=BlackRock Gets Nod to Set Up Mutual Fund Business in China (Revised) |url=https://news.yahoo.com/blackrock-gets-nod-set-mutual-135001227.html |access-date=2020-09-16 |website=news.yahoo.com |language=en-US}} In January 2020, [[PNC Financial Services|PNC]] sold its stake in BlackRock.{{cite news|last=SABATINI|first=PATRICIA|date=May 15, 2020|title=PNC sold its shares to Blackrock stake for $14.4 billion|work=[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]|url=https://www.post-gazette.com/business/pittsburgh-company-news/2020/05/15/PNC-sells-Blackrock-stake-for-14-4-billion/stories/202005150123}} As of 2021, BlackRock owns 7.50% of [[HSBC|HSBC Holdings plc]], making it the second single largest shareholder after [[Ping An Insurance]].{{cite news|date=September 27, 2020|title=China's Ping An Insurance boosts HSBC stake|work=Reuters|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-hsbc-hldg-ping-an-of-china-idUSKBN26I09Q}}{{cite web|date=December 31, 2020|title=SEC SCHEDULE 13G for HSBC HOLDINGS PLC|work=[[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission|SEC]]|url=https://www.marketwatch.com/investing/secfile/14651868}} ==Ownership and transparency== BlackRock invests the funds of its clients (for example, the owners of [[iShares]] [[exchange-traded fund|ETF]] units) in numerous publicly traded companies, some of which compete with each other.{{Cite journal |last1=Fichtner |first1=Jan |last2=Heemskerk |first2=Eelke M. |last3=Garcia-Bernardo |first3=Javier |date=2017 |title=Hidden power of the Big Three? {{dynamic list|date=July 2020}} == BlackRock Solutions== In 2000, BlackRock launched BlackRock Solutions, the analytics and risk management division of BlackRock, Inc. The division grew from the [[Aladdin (BlackRock)|Aladdin System]] (which is the enterprise investment system), Green Package (which is the Risk Reporting Service) PAG (portfolio analytics) and AnSer (which is the interactive analytics). BlackRock Solutions (BRS) serves two roles within BlackRock. First, BlackRock Solutions is the in-house investment analytics and “process engineering” department for BlackRock which works with their portfolio management teams, risk and quantitative analysis, business operations and every other part of the firm that touches the investment process. Second, BlackRock Solutions (BRS) and the three primary divisions are services that are offered to institutional clients. As of 2013, the platform had nearly 2,000 employees.[https://www.economist.com/news/briefing/21591164-getting-15-trillion-assets-single-risk-management-system-huge-achievement Briefing: BlackRock - The Monolith And The Markets], ''[[The Economist]]'', December 7, 2013, pp. 24-26. BlackRock differentiates itself from other asset managers by claiming its risk management is not separate. Risk management is the foundation and cornerstone of the firm's entire platform. Aladdin keeps track of 30,000 investment portfolios, including BlackRock's own along with those of competitors, banks, [[pension fund]]s, and insurers. According to ''[[The Economist]]'', as at December 2013, the platform monitors almost 7 percent of the world's $225 trillion of financial assets. BlackRock Solutions was retained by the [[U. S. Treasury Department]] in May 2009 to manage (i.e. analyze, unwind, and price) the [[toxic asset|toxic mortgage assets]] that were owned by [[Bear Stearns]], [[American International Group|AIG, Inc.]], December 2018, BlackRock was the world's largest investor in coal plant developers, holding shares worth $11 billion among 56 coal plant developers.{{Cite web |date=2018-12-05 |title=New Research Reveals the Banks and Investors Financing the Expansion of the Global Coal Plant Fleet |url=https://urgewald.org/medien/new-research-reveals-banks-and-investors-financing-expansion-global-coal-plant-fleet |website=Urgewald}} and BlackRock owned more oil, gas, and thermal coal reserves than any other investor with total reserves amounting to 9.5 gigatonnes of {{CO2}} emissions or 30 percent of total energy-related emissions from 2017.{{Cite web |date=2018-12-10 |title=New report confirms BlackRock's big fossil fuel problem |url=https://foe.org/news/new-report-confirms-blackrocks-big-fossil-fuel-problem/ |website=Friends of the Earth}} Environmental groups including the [[Sierra Club]],{{Cite web |date=2018-10-05 |title=New Campaign Is Calling Out BlackRock's Big Climate Problem |url=https://www.sierraclub.org/compass/2018/10/new-campaign-calling-out-blackrock-s-big-climate-problem |access-date=2019-01-24 |website=Sierra Club |language=en}} and [[Amazon Watch]]{{Cite web |title=BlackRock Targeted as Largest Driver of Climate Destruction in New Campaign due in part to its refusal to [[Fossil fuel divestment|divest from fossil fuel companies]]. On January 10, 2020, a group of climate activists rushed inside the Paris offices of BlackRock France, painting walls and floors with warnings and accusations on the responsibility of the company in the [[Effects of global warming|current climate and social crises]].{{Cite news |title=BlackRock's Paris Office Barricaded by Climate Activists |website=[[Bloomberg News]] |date=10 February 2020 |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-02-10/blackrock-s-paris-office-barricaded-by-climate-activists |access-date=2020-02-10 |language=en}} On January 14, 2020, BlackRock CEO [[Larry Fink]] said that environmental sustainability would be a key goal for investment decisions. BlackRock announced that it would sell $500 million worth of coal-related assets, and create funds that would avoid fossil-fuel stocks, two moves that would drastically shift the company's investment policy. Environmentalist [[Bill McKibben]] called this a "huge, if by no means final, win for activists." Nonetheless, BlackRock's support for shareholder resolutions requesting [[climate risk]] disclosure fell from 25% in 2019 to 14% in 2020 according to Morningstar Proxy Data.{{Cite web |last=Cook |first=Jackie |date=September 28, 2020 |title=How Big Fund Families Voted on Climate Change: 2020 Edition |url=https://www.morningstar.com/articles/1002749/how-big-fund-families-voted-on-climate-change-2020-edition |access-date=October 20, 2020 |website=Morningstar.com}} ===EU banking rules=== The [[European Ombudsman]] opened an inquiry in May 2020{{Cite web |title=European Ombudsman |url=https://www.ombudsman.europa.eu/fr/case/en/57060 |access-date=2020-09-23 |website=www.ombudsman.europa.eu}} to inspect the commission's file on the European Commission's decision to award a contract to BlackRock Investment Management to carry out a study on integrating environmental, social and governance risks and objectives into EU banking rules ('the prudential framework'). European Parliament members questioned{{Cite web |title=The Commission's decision to award a contract to BlackRock to oversee the development of ESG factors in the EU banking sector and corporate investment policies |url=https://www.europarl.europa.eu/doceo/document/P-9-2020-002369_EN.html |access-date=2020-09-23 |website=www.europarl.europa.eu |language=en}} the impartiality of the world's largest asset manager given its investments already in the sector. ===West Virginia=== [[Riley Moore]], the [[State treasurer|State Treasurer of West Virginia]], said in June 2022 that BlackRock and five other financial institutions would no longer be allowed to do business with the state of West Virginia, because of their advocacy against the fossil fuel industry. Moore said, "At a time when energy demand is skyrocketing and consumers are bearing the brunt of generationally high inflation, it makes absolutely no sense for financial institutions to cut off capital and financing to these legal, profitable industries simply because they don’t align with their radical social and political agendas."{{cite news |last1=Schroeder |first1=Pete |title=West Virginia threatens to bar big banks, BlackRock over perceived fossil fuel boycotts |url=https://www.reuters.com/business/finance/west-virginia-threatens-bar-big-banks-blackrock-over-perceived-fossil-fuel-2022-06-14/ |access-date=June 17, 2022 |publisher=Reuters |date=June 14, 2022}}
